title: 111_s3196
content:
The Act titled "Pre-Election Presidential Transition Act of 2010" allows eligible candidates to receive certain presidential transition services before the general election. The Administrator must notify candidates of their right to these services and facilities, providing a description of each. Upon the candidate's acceptance, the Administrator will provide the requested services. The Act allows eligible candidates to receive presidential transition services before the general election. The Administrator must notify candidates of their right to these services, including additional services under specific sections of the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004. Notifications are provided to major party candidates after their nominating convention and to other candidates promptly upon eligibility. The Administrator must prepare a report summarizing modern presidential transition activities before each general election for President and Vice-President. This report is made available to the public and provided to eligible candidates along with notice of their right to receive transition services. The Administrator determines office space location, ensures secure computers and communications services, offers assistance without political bias, and may adjust services for eligible candidates in preparation for assuming official duties as President or Vice-President. An eligible candidate may establish a separate fund for expenditures related to preparing for assuming official duties as President or Vice-President, including reimbursing the Administrator for any unauthorized use of services or facilities provided. The eligible candidate may establish a separate fund for expenditures related to preparing for assuming official duties as President or Vice-President, including transferring contributions received for the general election or payments from the Presidential Election Campaign Fund. This fund must qualify for section 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. An eligible candidate can establish a separate fund for expenditures related to preparing for assuming official duties as President or Vice-President. Expenditures from this fund must comply with campaign finance laws and reporting requirements. Eligible candidates must meet all requirements and limitations when soliciting or expending amounts, similar to the President-elect or Vice-President-elect. An eligible candidate for a presidential election is defined as a candidate of a major party for President or Vice-President, or any other candidate determined by the Administrator to be a principal contender. The Administrator must ensure that eligible candidates meet constitutional requirements and have qualified to appear on the ballot. An eligible candidate for a presidential election must have their name on the ballots of enough states with over 50% of the total electors, show significant public support in national polls, and be recognized as a principal contender by national organizations like the Commission on Presidential Debates. The Presidential Transition Act of 1963 is amended to require the Administrator to provide technology coordination upon request for the computer and communications systems of the President-elect, Vice-President-elect, or eligible candidate. Additionally, coordination with other transition services includes defining security clearances for eligible candidates. The Presidential Transition Act of 1963 is amended to include the term 'eligible candidate' and specify the transmission of electronic records to candidates for President. Conforming amendments are also made to the Act. The Presidential Transition Act of 1963 is amended to include the term 'eligible candidate' for President and Vice-President, allowing for planning and coordination of activities by the Executive branch for a smooth transfer of power. The Presidential Transition Act of 1963 is amended to establish a transition coordinating council with high-level officials selected by the President, an agency transition directors council, and guidance for Executive Departments and agencies on briefing materials for incoming administrations. The Presidential Transition Act of 1963 is amended to include the development of briefing materials for incoming administrations, computer software, contingency plans, issue memoranda, training programs, and other items to improve the efficiency of Presidential transitions. Assistance to eligible candidates is provided without political bias. The Presidential Transition Act of 1963 is amended to include reports on activities preparing for the transfer of power to a new President. Reports are to be provided six months and three months before the general election. Authorization of appropriations is granted for necessary expenses. The curr_chunk can be summarized as:
